heading: apple reaps a fine harvest
subheading: buoyed by robust sales of its imac and ibook computers, apple computer reports strong first-quarter earnings, well above wall street's expectations.
author: wired staff
text: apple computer, citing strong sales of its imac desktop and ibook laptop computers, posted fiscal first-quarter earnings on wednesday that handily beat wall street expectations. apple (aapl), headquartered in cupertino, california, said net income rose to us$183 million, or $1.03 a share, in its first quarter ended 1 january, up from $152 million (95 cents) a year earlier. excluding one-time items, apple's per share earnings were $1. on that basis, wall street analysts had expected earnings of 90 cents, according to first call/thomson financial.the latest quarter's results included a $5 million net favorable impact from non-recurring items. without those items, the company's net profit for the quarter would have come in at $178 million, up 45 percent from the same period a year earlier.revenues rose 37 percent to $2.34 billion from $1.7 billion a year earlier, but gross profit margins slipped to 25.9 percent from 28.2 percent in the year-ago quarter. international sales accounted for 51 percent of revenues in the quarter.for the quarter, apple said it sold 1.377 million systems, including more than 700,000 imac consumer desktops and 235,000 ibook consumer portables, for year-over-year unit growth of 46 percent. fred anderson, apple's chief financial officer, said he expected significant growth in unit sales and revenue in the current second fiscal quarter.apple also said its board had voted to grant the company's now permanent chief executive, steve jobs, options to purchase 10 million shares of apple common stock and give him a gulfstream v airplane.jobs said earlier this month that after 2-1/2 years as interim ceo, he was taking the position on a permanent basis.
